DA48920B53EF41038DB74474C45BA9DD.description: Describe the relationship between days, weeks, months, and years.

C18C2CB3C1524801818D8697B7968413.description: Relate First Nationsï¿½ winter counts to duration.

E3DF0F753A0F4E0EB35DC1F7289811B2.description: Describe the duration of events using non-standard units.

A52EEC983D1C4B8F9F69E949943D7D9F.description: Express significant events using calendar dates.

4391963207C84158B109B4357846FE2A.description: Duration is the measure of an amount of time from beginning to end.

BE80726C0B4E43F58760C15C3A2F3742.description: Time can be communicated in various ways.

502D90BCFA904A4181238E9FEADAAC4A.description: Time can be described using standard units such as days or minutes.

027D8D2F5CA54CF7A2D7ADA62FABA9BB.description: Duration can be measured in non-standard units, including events, natural cycles, or personal referents.

A0164311180249D8B1CE0372CB983D6E.description: Duration can be described using comparative language such as longer or shorter.

8ACA26856F374C86BE6D45506BA34670.description: Events can be related to calendar dates.

7E241CBA27544E03AD7910D6B17221D8.description: Create and express growing patterns using sounds, objects, pictures, or actions.

085824782FB840C194870F0F13C0E769.description: Investigate patterns in a hundreds chart.

1BF6479A8E52440F854040EBBE5B4CB8.description: Describe non-repeating patterns encountered in surroundings, including in art, architecture, cultural designs, and nature.

346E8C1395F248058EAB81A901045FA7.description: A pattern core can vary in complexity.

645BCB556F3B4CF8AC41D9F29C7A7A94.description: A pattern is more evident when the elements are represented, organized, aligned, or oriented in familiar ways.

B3A9FC3B17204DD5A50D207B50EA34AB.description: A pattern can show increasing or decreasing change.

25E8D9F0513D40D381AA897A7A8C3074.description: Attributes of elements, such as size and colour, can contribute to a pattern.

8412982A1F8A4E459F580EA7FA26784B.description: Students explain and analyze patterns in a variety of contexts.

E0FD4BBC6A8F47FCAC1EAC24F54F8260.description: Patterns: Awareness of patterns supports problem solving in various situations.

48D45A1C2B4D4A84BBE1A709F72FA7F9.description: Estimate length by visualizing the iteration of a referent for a centimetre.

4ED2293D6A9547088854CFC3175A0F44.description: Compare and order measurements of different lengths measured with centimetres.

5F9BE40CFCC0455EB7FBD968C4D78035.description: Measure length with standard units by tiling or iterating with a centimetre.

4B1B9D9E35204B2CB7768503E1E5C1F4.description: Compare measurements of the same length measured with different non-standard units.

1FFF88A8B8E146328861701B24CD3392.description: Compare and order measurements of different lengths measured with the same non-standard units, and explain the choice of unit.

D38726B0F6E64217BECB88666246493A.description: Measure length with non-standard units by tiling, iterating, or using a self-created measuring tool.

5CD6DE455DA24EA9B305F353850B08F3.description: Length can be estimated when a measuring tool is not available.

326F1D47D5E244F388BB8490723AADEA.description: The number of units required to measure a length is inversely related to the size of the unit.

0139C8F7CC06465C943F2D07811BFF36.description: Length is measured with equal-sized units that themselves have length.

E62A1E969EB64212AC2739D2C71111A2.description: A common referent from the land or body parts can be used to measure length.

49D059DF7C204B4BB76F9E91E61E3E31.description: A referent is a personal or familiar representation of a known length.

5A44EEC24CD94D03B957CA78ED95312A.description: Standard units, such as centimetres, can enable a common language around measurement.

90F333DF9A794BCD958ECB19EBCCF62D.description: Non-standard units found in nature can be used to measure length on the land.

2DE5E7ABADB445228848D6771E86F8D6.description: Length can be measured with non-standard units or standard units.

43677EDCF2B04F49A9173874135FB2F4.description: The unit can be chosen based on the length to be measured.

BAE1387B599F41B7B7BC100DE5110199.description: Iterating is the process of measuring a length by repeating one copy of a unit without gaps or overlaps.

457AA4B389BD4D28B27CD242442A3127.description: Tiling is the process of measuring a length by using many copies of a unit without gaps or overlaps.

F2AD5649B94D4345AFA62914C907DA8D.description: Measurement: Attributes such as length, area, volume, and angle are quantified by measurement.

0E556D2076E74D8A98AE9422EBCE57CA.description: Recognize the translation, rotation, or reflection of shapes represented in artwork.

1A9B2B8A4E804F90BA58AC7F877749C3.description: Describe geometric attributes of two- and three-dimensional shapes in various orientations.

8E44E6CF290E4F7CA33E08C59AC0EFDC.description: Investigate translation, rotation, and reflection of two- and three-dimensional shapes.

BC2D6135CD594AE18C1B99AFF99A4C3A.description: Create a picture or design with shapes from verbal instructions, visualization, or memory.

4F7A8B2F7015479B92FE406F2F328368.description: Relate the faces of three-dimensional shapes to two-dimensional shapes.

907B74877FE04671AF682092475FBC43.description: Sort shapes according to two geometric attributes and describe the sorting rule.

568A7C35658E431292BECE5F5FCCA2A2.description: Geometric attributes do not change when a shape is translated, rotated, or reflected.

66F2E3F4CC734A8CBD5A65C5E0D2AFCB.description: A shape can be visualized as a composition of other shapes.

157A1E4F80B74C5583EB1174B5296AEC.description: Shapes are defined according to geometric attributes.

C0EAFB47C4FC41FFA0F7D4D4D7F8CEE0.description: Shapes can be turned or flipped in the creation of art.

8F028BEEB0DC4E43A7767B666289CFE8.description: A shape can change orientation or position through slides (translations), turns (rotations), or flips (reflections).

2F4E7B7F0056449FAFCB064413D53F0E.description: Three-dimensional shapes may have faces that are two-dimensional shapes.

72CF4EC5FDDA4515898ECEEFC3BA655D.description: Two-dimensional shapes may have sides that are line segments.

838BB3E6081349CBB942D9E27D1B6AE1.description: Common geometric attributes include sides, vertices and faces or surfaces.

434049F280D34784BFF244E7FB20A3F8.description: Students analyze and explain geometric attributes of shape.

1E39AB854D8D4ADA997E362B6F5AFBE3.description: Geometry: Shapes are defined and related by geometric attributes.

5AC88F34F5384E45AE04610559471A13.description: Compare different unit fractions of the same whole, limited to denominators of 10 or less.

C8BCDD5C9E5F481DB440C08DA73FF5DD.description: Model a unit fraction by partitioning a whole object or whole set into equal parts, limited to 10 or fewer equal parts.

C5E6D83319C04489AA7EFCB5991162A9.description: One whole can be interpreted as a number of unit fractions.

6C9D6810179141C0A638298928D2486E.description: A unit fraction describes any one of the equal parts that compose a whole.

7467B115A6734E9A8B64A9EC41E0B836.description: The whole can be any size and is designated by context.

02E751FC7154457CACF043C710DE2950.description: A whole can be a whole set of objects, or a whole object, that can be partitioned into a number of equal parts.

75EBE294049342F48718A091D0F98A1B.description: Students interpret part-whole relationships using unit fractions.

4D94F4019A9945D4AE585792E6A7A3BA.description: Solve problems using addition and subtraction of countable quantities or measurable lengths.

40D1D883B83A4BF2A7F141736C1BB537.description: Determine a missing quantity in a sum or difference, within 100, in a variety of ways.

3389866830E448DFB9D8B397B9B2410D.description: Verify a sum or difference using inverse operations.

04503398D7BA472FB7D73F2DCDE5C9E2.description: Recall and apply addition number facts, with addends to 10, and related subtraction number facts.

8D24D1CE52594A77B10227BFBB43B773.description: Visualize 100 as a composition of multiples of 10 in various ways.

A0C10BF848A14157B17716B5759D93A3.description: Addition and subtraction can represent the sum or difference of countable quantities or measurable lengths.

BE7E5C8B88AE4D05B9F2E6DBC6B75C64.description: Addition and subtraction strategies for two-digit numbers include making multiples of ten and using doubles.

B09E5664A4B7471D84C57A53F43A6BE9.description: Familiar addition and subtraction number facts facilitate addition and subtraction strategies.

5F3CA6BF64A54F61A09C443169E01DC1.description: The order in which more than two numbers are added does not affect the sum (associative property).

0FFA642EC3524D25B347BA8FEB61D011.description: Students investigate addition and subtraction within 100.

FF2DFCBD6705440E8E933EE8BCE6319F.description: Describe a quantity as less than, greater than, or equal to another quantity.

5E404C5FB5FD47F18A416EB750BC88BB.description: Model equality and inequality between two quantities, including with a balance.

5218B1F735664B49BC7F44B63A4A2AA4.description: Partition a set of objects by sharing or grouping, with or without remainders.

AA22C11C610B4AA9A8197E7D8F616548.description: Describe a quantity as even or odd.

6D7E77CDB0C94E8A991C3E089F50A725.description: Model even and odd quantities by sharing and grouping.

6245522C9F314B7EBE9B394A008FE241.description: Determine the value of a collection of coins or bills of the same denomination by skip counting.

90630A7DAB3041888F57758525C27AD6.description: Skip count by 2s and 10s, starting at any number.

DA9614D958044489AC3588D5B9FB54A9.description: Skip count by 20s, 25s, or 50s, starting at 0.

91154D2637244CB4A47BECAC99A5322B.description: Count within 1000, forward and backward by 1s, starting at any number.

6F987B4813A94EDAA7D60A68978CFD55.description: Decompose quantities into groups of 100s, 10s, and 1s.

2FE1EA14DF6F49D7BA8E13C4538E472B.description: Relate a number, including zero, to its position on the number line.

C64601E3871F417497859CFEDAF5CD8C.description: Identify the digits representing thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones based on place in a natural number.

7342FBA5EA9D4D3EB9E7E52D38990B60.description: Represent quantities using words and natural numbers.

DCFA7D5A4C6E43B1A34C5900D64F04A1.description: Inequality is an imbalance between two quantities.

63AF13D63DF1417EB3EFC748A6B61392.description: A quantity can be estimated when an exact count is not needed.

78E837213C9840D08E6FC7408F9B2721.description: All natural numbers are either even or odd.

7E179C1BED1243CAA8CEE00199BF5347.description: A quantity can be interpreted as a composition of groups.

5287E84E941741DB9C43CC539908E564.description: Each natural number is associated with exactly one point on the number line.

75E57A468ACF44249DBAFC70351E329C.description: Every digit in a natural number has a value based on its place.

39F4BB899C024EF7805249F611015642.description: There are infinitely many natural numbers.

B9AD81A9880A40B38F43B00530B5AD05.description: Equality and inequality can be modelled using a balance.

A648804367B74FC5A9C594717E0B40FC.description: The less than sign, <, and the greater than sign, >, are used to indicate inequality between two quantities.

D2676673FFEE4AE3A487360140070668.description: Words that can describe a comparison between two unequal quantities include not equal, greater than and less than.

B3A17E3490EA457A87F39F46B756D328.description: A benchmark is a known quantity to which another quantity can be compared.

14072F4982AA46C18576FDB33FDB8575.description: An odd quantity will have a remainder of one when partitioned into two equal groups or groups of two.

4F7F9BD974924BEE909BCE901B62FA64.description: An even quantity will have no remainder when partitioned into two equal groups or groups of two.

A0EC7DC19C944033B2502A4DEA88478F.description: Quantities of money can be skip counted in amounts that are represented by coins and bills (denominations).

D9BED65BEEBA4B0E865243017A9D7D39.description: A quantity can be skip counted in various ways according to context.

BA26EE2E23EE4FC99F35D972076642E7.description: The number line is a spatial representation of quantity.

04BDA30CA16B4550837D31FC895D2499.description: Places that have no value within a given number use zero as a placeholder.

81731F699924426796F82A1B2CDA2B57.description: The values of the places in a four-digit natural number are thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones.

99E7AC0475804E0CB2AA8DF68692A0DB.description: Any number of objects in a set can be represented by a natural number.

BAF3AFE900CB494F86C6DC11F485DCBA.description: Number: Quantity is measured with numbers that enable counting, labelling, comparing, and operating.
